MC100.name: Freshmen Success Seminar
MC100.description: Exploration of academic, social, personal and career decisions that students face in college, with a primary focus on the first year and the James Madison College experience.
MC100.restrictions: Open to freshmen in the James Madison College or in the James Madison-No Major.

MC111.name: Identity and Community: An Approach to Writing I
MC111.description: Identity and community in American and cross-cultural contexts. Influences of family, education, work, religion, gender, race, class and/or sexuality on identity and community. Critical reading and analytical writing and public speaking.
MC111.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC112.name: Identity and Community: An Approach to Writing II
MC112.description: Identity and community in American and cross-cultural contexts in selected historical eras. Reconstructing images of self and society in time of stress or transition. History, narrative, literature, film, art, politics. Principles of research, documentation, persuasive writing, and public speaking.
MC112.restrictions: Open to students in the James Madison College.

MC181.name: Introduction to Science, Technology, the Environment and Public Policy
MC181.description: Relation of science and technology to ethics and public policy. Environmental law and public policy. Managing fish, water and wildlife resources at state, national, and international levels. Science and technology in developing countries. Impacts of military technology on environmental policy.

MC201.name: Introduction to the Study of Public Affairs I
MC201.description: Interdisciplinary exploration of enduring issues and conflicts in American and international public affairs. Historical, social science, and comparative approaches.
MC201.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the James Madison College. Approval of college.

MC202.name: Introduction to the Study of Public Affairs II
MC202.description: Continued interdisciplinary exploration of enduring issues and conflicts in American and international public affairs. Historical, social science, and comparative approaches.

MC220.name: International Relations I: World Politics and International Security
MC220.description: Evolution of the contemporary international system. Theories, explanations, and comparisons of actions and interactions of state and non-state actors. Causes of war and peace.
MC220.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the James Madison College.

MC221.name: International Relations II: The Politics of International Economic Relations
MC221.description: Theories and policy issues in international political economy. Analysis of trade, money and finance, technology, transnational corporations, debt and environment. Globalization, hegemonic power, international regimes.

MC230.name: Cultures and Politics in Comparative Perspective
MC230.description: Interdisciplinary and comparative approaches to analysis of culture and politics. Whole culture, structuralist, post structuralist, and interpretive theories of culture. Analysis of the relationship of political regimes, cultural diversity, identity, and representation, and case studies.

MC231.name: Cultures and Politics in Transnational Perspective
MC231.description: Interdisciplinary study of cross-cultural interactions and transnational politics in the context of globalization. Competing approaches to inter-cultural interaction. Case studies of cultural conflict, assimilation, and hybridization. Legacies of imperialism and colonialism. Narratives and representations of transnational interactions.

MC270.name: Classical Republicanism
MC270.description: Theory and practice of popular government in classical Greece and Rome. Rebirth of such forms in the cities and monarchies of Medieval and Renaissance Europe.
MC270.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the James Madison College.

MC271.name: Constitutionalism and Democracy
MC271.description: Origins and development of liberal constitutionalism and its democratization. Theory and practice of the modern state, especially the American variant.

MC272.name: Political Theory and Political Issues
MC272.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MC272.description: Selected issues in political theory or specific political problems. Topics vary.

MC280.name: Social Theory and Social Relations
MC280.description: Classical and contemporary theories of social structure, intergroup process, inequality, and social change. Class, ethnicity, race, gender, social stratification, social mobility and conflict.
MC280.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC281.name: Immigrants, Minorities, and American Pluralism
MC281.description: Comparative social history of American peoples, focused on immigrants and ethnic and racial minorities. Comparisons of patterns of adjustment, intergroup relations, and politics.
MC281.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC290.name: Special Topics
MC290.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MC290.description: Selected topics in public affairs including issues in international relations, political theory and constitutional democracy, social relations and policy, and comparative cultures and politics.
MC290.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC293.name: Methods for Strategic Analysis in Public Affairs
MC293.description: Basic methods of strategic analysis and game theory. Applications and case studies in international relations, politics, political economy, and social relations.
MC293.prerequisite: (MTH 110 or MTH 116 or MTH 112 or MTH 114 or MTH 124 or MTH 132 or STT 200) or designated score on Mathematics Placement test

MC295.name: Research Design and Quantitative Analysis in Public Policy
MC295.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MC295.description: Design and execution of research in public policy analysis and evaluation. Critical evaluation of data and arguments. Data collection, hypothesis testing, survey of measures of association and evaluation.

MC299.name: Independent Study
MC299.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MC299.description: Individual reading and research under faculty direction.
MC299.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students. Approval of college.

MC300.name: Collaborative Study
MC300.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MC300.description: Group reading, research or simulations under faculty direction.

MC318.name: Chinese Foreign Policy
MC318.description: Theory, process and patterns of Chinese foreign policy. Underlying forces that shape Chinese foreign policy. Assumptions and bureaucratic processes of China's foreign policymaking.
MC318.prerequisite: (MC 220) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
MC318.restrictions: Open to students in the James Madison College.

MC319.name: Asian American History
MC319.description: Survey of Asian American history from mid-nineteenth century to present. Analysis of shared and different experiences of the Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Filipino, Vietnamese, Hmong, and East Indian peoples who have come to the United States.
MC319.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

MC320.name: Politics, Society and Economy in the Third World
MC320.description: Politics of social and economic change. Policies and strategies of development and of state and nation building in Third World countries. Impact of international political, security, and economic structures on the process of state and nation building in the Third World.
MC320.prerequisite: (MC 221 or MC 231 or MC 281) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC321.name: The Cold War: Culture, Politics and Foreign Policy
MC321.description: Cultural representations to explore the Cold War's balance of power politics and domestic consequences.
MC321.prerequisite: (MC 220 or MC 231) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC322.name: International Security
MC322.description: Analysis of selected classic and/or contemporary theories and issues in international security, which could include humanitarian intervention, human security, weapons of mass destruction, ethnic and religious conflict, environmental security, terrorism and changing ways of warfare.

MC324A.name: Regional Politics, Cooperation, and Conflict in the Middle East
MC324A.semester: Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MC324A.description: Sources of conflict and cooperation in the Middle East through case studies such as the Arab-Israeli conflict. Intrastate, regional, and global factors.
MC324A.prerequisite: (MC 220 or PLS 160) or completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC324C.name: Regional Politics, Cooperation, and Conflict in Latin America and the Caribbean
MC324C.description: Domestic and international politics of Latin American or Caribbean countries. Conflict and cooperation among states of the region. Government policies to promote security, democracy, and growth.
MC324C.prerequisite: (MC 220 or PLS 160) or completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC324D.name: Regional Politics, Cooperation, and Conflict in Asia
MC324D.description: Sources and consequences of conflict and cooperation in Asia. Conflict and cooperation among states of the region. Government policies to promote security, democracy, and growth.
MC324D.prerequisite: (MC 220 or PLS 160) or completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC324E.name: Regional Politics, Cooperation, and Conflict in Europe
MC324E.description: Sources and consequences of conflict and cooperation in Europe. Government policies to promote security, democracy, and growth.
MC324E.prerequisite: (MC 220 or PLS 160) or completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC325.name: State and Society in Comparative Perspective
MC325.description: Comparison of political systems and social-economic structures in capitalist and state-socialist societies. Political history, institutions, culture, and current policy issues.
MC325.prerequisite: (MC 221 or MC 271 or MC 230 or MC 281) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC326.name: U.S. Foreign Policy
MC326.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MC326.description: U.S. foreign policy decision-making structures and processes. Domestic and international determinants of foreign policy. Evolution of U.S. foreign policy.
MC326.prerequisite: (MC 221) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC328.name: Russian Foreign Policy
MC328.description: Evolution of Russian and Soviet foreign policy. Foreign policy decision-making structures and processes and domestic and international determinants of foreign policy.
MC328.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC329.name: European Security: Challenges and Strategies
MC329.description: Evolution of challenges facing Europe in post-cold war period. Critical examination of alternative policies and structures proposed in response to these challenges.
MC329.prerequisite: (MC 221) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC331.name: Encounters With Post-Communism
MC331.description: Interdisciplinary approach to the study of the cultural politics of post-communism and of international relations with countries of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.
MC331.prerequisite: ((MC 230 or MC 231 or MC 220)or approval of college) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
MC331.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the James Madison College.

MC332.name: Literature and Politics in a Comparative Perspective
MC332.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MC332.description: Comparative examination of literary representations of politics and political themes involving different national literatures, literary genres and/or other narrative forms.
MC332.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC332.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the James Madison College.

MC333.name: Performance, Politics, and Nation
MC333.description: Analysis of theories of and approaches to political performances and constructions of cultural nationalism, which includes social construction theory, the sociology of performance, ethnography, ethnomusicology and folklore, and critical approaches to nationalism, from classic studies to issues in gender, race, and post-colonialism.
MC333.prerequisite: MC 230 or MC 231 or MC 280 or MC 281 or approval of college
MC333.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC334.name: Rights, Advocacy, and Activism
MC334.description: Global perspectives on human rights, non-governmental organization (NGO) advocacy, and grassroots activism as mechanisms of change. Case studies on racial and cultural discrimination, gender-based violence, sexuality and rights, environment and climate justice, refugees and immigration, and other topics.
MC334.prerequisite: MC 230 or MC 231 or MC 280 or MC 281 or approval of college
MC334.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the James Madison College.

MC335.name: Israeli Politics, Cultures and Society
MC335.description: Analysis of Israeli politics and society. Relationship between society and
MC335.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC337.name: Global Public Health
MC337.description: Comprehensive, interdisciplinary and policy-orientated approach to global public health. Examination of infectious disease, as well as case studies.
MC337.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC341.name: Politics and Markets
MC341.description: Comparative study of economic organization via firms, markets, and governments. Political economy approaches to evaluation of the firm, market, and government organization. Normative principles for evaluating firm, market, and government organization.

MC348.name: Educational Policy
MC348.description: Examination of alternative policies to improve K-12 educational outcomes, including school finance, educational standards, teacher professional development, and school choice.
MC348.prerequisite: (EC 201 or EC 251H) or completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC349.name: Economics of Legal Relationships in Comparative Perspective
MC349.description: Survey and comparison of major schools of legal-economic thought, and their implications for policy. Economic impacts of law and legal institutions.
MC349.prerequisite: (EC 201 or EC 251H) or completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC350.name: Evolution and Society
MC350.description: The reciprocal relationship between evolutionary science and American culture. Social, political, and economic influences that shape biological scientists' descriptions of evolutionary change and their claims about evolutionary influence on cultures.
MC350.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC351.name: Science and Social Policy
MC351.description: Role that scientific research on group differences plays in creating and maintaining social stereotypes and policy. Practical implications of scientific research, sources of bias among scientific investigators, and the role of scientists in creating and changing stereotypes and in attacking social prejudice.
MC351.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC358.name: Politics of the U.S.S.R. and Its Successor States
MC358.description: Political history, communist ideology, state institutions, and political processes in the Soviet Union and its successor states.

MC361.name: Political Economy and Comparative Public Policymaking
MC361.description: Use of political economy approaches to explain public policies and policymaking processes in comparative perspective.
MC361.prerequisite: (MC 221 or MC 231) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC362.name: Public International Law
MC362.description: Impact of international law on social, political and economic change in the international system. Military conflict and conflict resolution, economic prosperity and redistribution, human rights and ecology. Origin and operation of international laws.
MC362.prerequisite: (MC 221) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC363.name: Global Governance
MC363.description: Impact of international institutions on social, political, and economic change in the international system. Evolution and devolution of global governance in international trade and finance, the environment, and military security.
MC363.prerequisite: (MC 221) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC364.name: Policy Evaluation
MC364.description: Economic concepts and analytic techniques for the design and evaluation of public policies. Political environment of policy formation and implementation. Basic data analysis. Application of concepts and techniques to selected government policies.
MC364.prerequisite: ((EC 201 or concurrently) or (EC 251H or concurrently)) and ((EC 202 or concurrently) or (EC 252H or concurrently)) and ((SOC 281 or concurrently) or (MC 295 or concurrently) or (PLS 201 or concurrently)) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC366.name: Film, History and Nation
MC366.description: Relation of film and cinema to nationalism, nation building, and national identity construction. Relation of film to history and historical representation. Role of domestic and international feature films in the formation of local, national, and global identities.
MC366.prerequisite: (MC 221 or MC 230 or MC 231 or approval of college) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC367.name: Global Cities and Urbanism
MC367.description: An interdisciplinary approach to the dynamic global system of cities and the local ways of urban life embedded in global structures. Cities as crucibles of power, production, and development at the neighborhood, city and regional levels.

MC368.name: The Civil Rights Movement and its Legacies
MC368.description: History of the U.S. civil rights movement. Race, class and gender dimensions. National and local perspectives. Aims, strategies, and achievements. Relevance to contemporary social movements.
MC368.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC368.restrictions: Open to students in the James Madison College.

MC369.name: Global Issues in Citizenship (W)
MC369.description: History and political theory of citizenship, including citizenship laws and policies; classical, liberal and republican perspectives; gender and race; national, postnational, and transnational citizenship.
MC369.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC369.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC370.name: Radical Challenges to Liberal Democracy
MC370.description: Criticisms of constitutionalism and liberal democracy. Theory and practice of 19th and early 20th century attempts to perfect or transcend bourgeois life through radical reform or revolution.
MC370.prerequisite: (MC 271) or completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC371.name: Beyond Liberal Democracy? New Directions in Political Theory
MC371.description: The contemporary status of liberal democracy. Theory and practice of late 20th century attempts to perfect, transcend, or undermine liberal democracy in light of crisis of rationalism.
MC371.prerequisite: (MC 370) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC372.name: Comparative Black Political Thought
MC372.description: Comparative examination of the political thought of blacks in the United States, Africa, and elsewhere in the African Diaspora
MC372.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC373A.name: Constitutionalism: The Supreme Court
MC373A.description: Theory of constitutional democracy through examination of selected Supreme Court cases. History of the Supreme Court and principles of constitutionalism.
MC373A.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC373A.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC373B.name: Constitutionalism: The Presidency
MC373B.description: The Presidency in American constitutional democracy. Origins and development of the executive, constitutional issues, presidential practice.
MC373B.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC373B.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC373c.name: Constitutionalism: Congress
MC373c.description: Congress in American constitutional democracy. Origins and development of the legislative branch, constitutional issues, and legislative practice in Congress.
MC373c.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC373c.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC375.name: Contemporary Developments in American Politics
MC375.description: Contemporary developments related to persistent issues of American governance. Normative, empirical, and historical inquiry into topics such as the role of popular opinion, policy capacities and democratic and deliberative practice. Examination of case studies. Selected policy problems.
MC375.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC375.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC376.name: Modern Political Thought in the Muslim World
MC376.description: Major intellectual transformations in the Muslim world from 19th century to the present. Important internal and external influences.
MC376.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC377.name: Culture, Politics and Post-Colonialism
MC377.description: International politics and power. Relations of colonialism and post-colonialism. Contemporary repercussions. History, literature, culture, and political theory.
MC377.prerequisite: (MC 221 or MC 271 or MC 231 or MC 281) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC378.name: Law and Social Groups
MC378.description: Relationship between fundamental law and the activity of social groups in the American context. Selected Supreme Court, Appellate and State Supreme Court cases examined for their impact on the free exercise and equal protection of social groups.
MC378.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC378.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC380.name: Social Policy
MC380.description: Application of social theory and methods to analysis of contemporary U.S. social policy. Competing explanations, current debates. Civil rights, education, employment, family, immigration, poverty, social welfare.
MC380.prerequisite: ((MC 280 or MC 281) or completion of Tier I writing requirement) and ((EC 201 or concurrently) or (EC 251H or concurrently)) and ((EC 202 or concurrently) or (EC 252H or concurrently))

MC381.name: American Politics and Equality
MC381.description: Controversies over equality in American thought, politics, constitutional practice, and public policy. Case studies.
MC381.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I writing requirement.
MC381.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC382.name: Social Movements
MC382.description: Theories and case studies of social movements in comparative perspective. Origins, development, membership, organizational dynamics, social control, political effects.
MC382.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC382.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC383.name: African American Politics
MC383.description: Contemporary African American politics. National and local politics, alternative political strategies and public policies. Advancement of African-American community.
MC383.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC384.name: Metropolitan Society
MC384.description: Restructuring of urban and metropolitan society and social relations in 20th century America. Contemporary patterns of social life, relations, and politics in post-industrial metropolis.
MC384.prerequisite: (MC 280 or MC 281) and ((EC 201 or concurrently) or (EC 251H or concurrently)) and ((EC 202 or concurrently) or (EC 252H or concurrently)) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC385.name: Comparative Race and Ethnic Relations
MC385.description: Advanced theories, cross national comparisons, and case studies of race and ethnic relations. Intergroup competition, conflict, dominance, accommodation, assimilation, and creolization. Prejudice, stereotypes, racism, ideologies, and political and economic processes.
MC385.prerequisite: (MC 220 or MC 281 or MC 230) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC386.name: Women and Power in Comparative Perspective
MC386.description: Application of feminist theory to questions of gender and power in different economic and political systems and geographic areas.
MC386.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC386.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the James Madison College.

MC387.name: Jews and Anti-Semitism
MC387.description: Comparative history and sociology of modern Jewish experiences. Anti-Semitism and intergroup relations; the Holocaust and responses to the Holocaust; assimilation and pluralism in the U.S.
MC387.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC387.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the James Madison College.

MC388.name: Sexual Politics: Historical and Contemporary Perspectives
MC388.description: Sexuality and gender in nineteenth and twentieth century history and politics. Social change, social movements, and sex roles.
MC388.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC388.restrictions: Open to students in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC389.name: Religious Politics in U.S. Society: Left, Right, and Other
MC389.description: Role of religion in politics and society, especially the role religion plays in political mobilization, and the nature of political diversity within U.S. religious traditions.
MC389.prerequisite: ((MC 280 or SOC 100 or SOC 488) or approval of college) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC390.name: Advanced Topics in Public Affairs
MC390.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MC390.description: Issues in international relations, political theory and constitutional democracy, social relations and policy, and comparative cultures and politics.
MC390.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC390.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC391.name: Selected Topics in Public Affairs
MC391.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC395.name: Cultural Dimensions of Public Affairs
MC395.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MC395.description: Multiple interrelations between culture and public affairs in American and/or cross-cultural contexts. Uses literature, film, criticism, and history to illuminate issues of conflict, power, and social structure in a variety of historical and geographical contexts.
MC395.prerequisite: (MC 112 and MC 202) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC399.name: Advanced Independent Study
MC399.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MC399.description: Advanced individual reading and research under faculty direction.
MC399.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC399.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors. Approval of college.

MC400.name: Field Experience
MC400.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MC400.description: Practical internship experience with a public, private, or non-profit organization engaged in making, influencing, implementing, or analyzing policy relevant to college program.
MC400.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the James Madison College.

MC401.name: Field Experience: Analysis and Interpretation
MC401.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MC401.description: Analysis and interpretation of field experience, sponsoring organization, or related policy issues under faculty direction.
MC401.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC401.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the James Madison College.

MC410.name: Research in Public Affairs
MC410.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MC410.description: Faculty supervised undergraduate research in public and international affairs.
MC410.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the James Madison College. Approval of college.

MC411.name: Advanced Collaborative Study in Public Affairs
MC411.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MC411.description: Faculty supervised undergraduate research in public and international affairs.
MC411.restrictions: Open to students in the James Madison College. Approval of college; application required. A student may earn a maximum of 0 credits N/A

MC412.name: Public Affairs in Practice
MC412.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MC412.description: Faculty or practitioner in residence course that enables students to learn from experienced professionals in the field of public and international affairs.
MC412.restrictions: Open to students in the James Madison College. Approval of college.

MC430.name: Applied International Development
MC430.description: Comprehensive, interdisciplinary and applied approach to international development policy and practice. Examination of key thematic areas as well as case studies
MC430.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC441.name: Islam and World Politics
MC441.description: Manifestations of political Islam within key Muslim countries such as Turkey, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Iran, and Pakistan. Use of political Islam by states and groups as an instrument to advance their international goals.
MC441.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC445.name: Biodiversity Conservation Policy and Practice
MC445.description: Social, economic, and policy considerations. Approaches to conserve biodiversity.
MC445.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

MC446.name: International Energy Policy (W)
MC446.description: Analysis of theories and dilemmas within international energy policy, which could include energy security and geopolitics, energy governance institutions, energy poverty, sustainable energy and battery storage, global oil markets, 'fracking', and international dam building.
MC446.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC446.restrictions: Open to students in the James Madison College or in the Science, Technology, Environment and Public Policy Minor.

MC450.name: International Environmental Law and Policy
MC450.description: Overview of concepts, actors, norms, laws, and institutions related to international environmental policy. Case studies on current global environmental issues.

MC459.name: Science, Technology, Environment and Public Policy Capstone
MC459.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MC459.description: Selected topics in science, technology, environment and public policy (STEPPS). Analysis of key issues and problems. Case studies.
MC459.prerequisite: (FW 181 or approval of college) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC469.name: Applied Public Policy Research Seminar
MC469.description: Research on a public policy issue organized to develop a policy proposal collectively designed by all students in the class.
MC469.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the James Madison College.

MC481.name: Global Issues in Fisheries and Wildlife
MC481.description: Global issues and their impacts on implications for the management of fisheries and wildlife resources.
MC481.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC481.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

MC482.name: Gender and Violent Conflict
MC482.description: Gender consequences of a range of violent conflicts and their resolution. Theoretical contours and policy implications of gendered conflict within and between states. Contemporary case studies.
MC482.prerequisite: ((MC 220 or MC 270 or MC 280 or ANP 220 or WS 201 or SOC 216 or MC 231) or approval of college) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MC490H.name: Honors Independent Study
MC490H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MC490H.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors. Approval of college.

MC492.name: Senior Seminar in International Relations (W)
MC492.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MC492.description: Major issues and theories of international relations.
MC492.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC492.restrictions: Open to seniors in the International Relations Major. Approval of college.

MC493.name: Senior Seminar in Comparative Cultures and Politics (W)
MC493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MC493.description: Advanced study of selected issues in the study of comparative cultures and politics.
MC493.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
MC493.restrictions: Open to seniors or approval of college.

MC495H.name: Senior Honors Thesis
MC495H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MC495H.description: Academic year-long thesis; topic related to student's field.
MC495H.restrictions: Open to seniors in the James Madison College. Approval of college.

MC497.name: Senior Seminar in Political Theory and Constitutional Democracy (W)
MC497.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MC497.description: Selected problems in political theory and constitutional democracy. Relationship between theory and politics. Analysis of key thinkers. Case studies.
MC497.prerequisite: (MC 371) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
MC497.restrictions: Open to seniors in the James Madison College or approval of college.

MC498.name: Senior Seminar in Social Relations (W)
MC498.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MC498.description: American social relations and policy. Theoretical issues. Analysis of key thinkers. Case studies.
MC498.prerequisite: (MC 380) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
MC498.restrictions: Open to seniors in the James Madison College or approval of college.
